The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#14707](https://drahtbot.github.io/bitcoin_core_issue_redirect/r/14707.html) ([RPC] Include coinbase transactions in rece

utACK fa0c24c96e9937f666dcdd83d12145720c7b0329\nSomehow I would be in favour of putting brackets around descriptive values (`(null)` instead of `null` and `(fallback to nodeid)` instead of `fallback to nodeid`) to avoid confusion between real default values and behavioural description.

> I don't think saying (default=null) or (default=omitted) is ever helpful. (...) I actually think it would be better to drop the all the (default=null) and (default=omitted) strings if they can't be replaced with something more constructive, to avoid creating a bad precedent for future changes.\n\nIf there is "default=" string outputted for each optional argument, functional test could be made

> If there is "default=" string outputted for each optional argument, functional test could be made that checks that people don't forget to document optional argument defaults for a new RPCs.\n\nIMO, better to write that test with a list of exceptions for grandfathered, undocumented default arguments, than to leave bad documentation scattered over the codebase, especially since existing document
Oh, yes, short list of a few exceptions probably is better idea.
I have changes piled up locally to enforce that it is either a required arg or a default value is provided at compile time.

@MarcoFalke what do you want to do with all the `(default=null)` / `(default=omitted)` cruft? Do you want to address it in a future PR or maybe mark this one up for grabs so someone else can fill in useful default values?
@ryanofsky Your suggestion is a one-line change after #14918, so either you leave feedback there or create a pull request after #14918 is merged.
what about using a stringprint of the `threshold` variable?
/If set/If true/ might be more accurate
